title: Just played a game that may have Defeated me from Playing this game again.
body:
Just had a game where there was a player who's name was the Name of an ISIS member known for the beheading of people worldwide. The very first words said in the game was the N-word by his teammate.

I said "that's not a funny joke" where a 3rd person told me to "grow thicker skin".

Racism is not funny, ISIS is not a joke, saying the N-word and defending his spam of the N-word all game is not acceptable.

I really love this game but it's players like this that give me an overwhelming sense of Negativity Bias and the sense I simply do not belong
in this community.

Chances are I won't quit this game right now, however it's becoming more and more likely with each passing day of seeing this behavior, that I might 
just leave the game.


I know nobody cares and i'm just 1 person, and I know the downvotes will come, but I just had to get this off my chest.

Thanks.

replies.body:
Downvotes not coming, bro.

Report that junk. Those are the people that get banned fastest. Riot takes slurs VERY SERIOUSLY. I have NEVER seen anyone get banned faster than someone using slurs. 

And that's why I still have faith that someday, I will get a game with no toxic buttholes. Someday. If you enjoy the game, don't let people like that stop you. If you must mute, mute. And make sure to report. Every legit report makes the community a little bit safer.

It's not really as bad as supporting ISIS, but one player suggested I commit suicide by cutting my veins (plus at the similar time he went 0/56 in one game, Zilean mid, it really looked like trolling his teammates). I reported him to Support System (he told me that after game in private chat, so hardly could I report him at post-in-game screen) and he still plays unbanned (I check his Match History and its dates now and then). I am not the nicest person and I wasn't really bothered by the player (so I don't mind much) but I though Riot takes those things "very seriously".

I really hope those people get punished but from my experience I wouldn't expect it strongly.

Well, the situation you describe is a bit different, from a legal standpoint. Private chat is a different matter entirely.

They can hardly ban people for saying terrible things with their friends... and if you're private chatting him, he has to be on your friends list, no? He could easily argue, in court, that Riot has no right to ban him for a private chat. And they don't. So they won't.

I agree it's a terrible thing to say regardless of where, but you have to remember that Riot isn't keen on getting sued, whether he's a good person or not. It's their business to keep things civil in the game environment. Outside of that, they really don't have much say in the matter. That doesn't mean they don't take it seriously.

He wanted to add me into his friend list only to say this. I added him because I though he might wanted to end the discussion we had in the game, but not like this. But I agree it may be very easily abusable so hard to decide there.

Yeah, I know you didn't MEAN to get told off by someone on your friend's list. 

He's just abusing the system, that's exactly right. It's just much easier to punish people for their in game behavior than out of game.

That's not how it works. RIOT (and every company) has blinded itself really well with their ToS, you don't even own your account, legally they own an account that they give you access to. They could literally permaban you right now with the reason "we felt like it" and, it the end, you could dispute nothing to them because the ToS you've agreed with says that they can do so.

Also, whether you can say or not slurs is *really* subjective. You can tell racist jokes to your friends or strangers in your friend list and nothing would probably happen to you, but if, for whatever reason, a judge wants to imprison you for it, trust me they'll find a way to do so. I don't live in the U.S. so it may be different there, but I'm 99% sure they can do that in whatever country.
Granted if they did because they felt like it it would cause a bit of a community uproar
Of course, I was just pointing out that they can do whatever they want with your account.
